author: mwrock
body:
I found the note regarding the dotnet CLI version misleading. I initially had compile errors due to an unrelated issue and spent a good chunk of time trying to ensure the dotnet cli 1.0.0 was installed. On a clean VM, after `start-psbootstrap` running `dotnet` produces:

```
PS C:\dev\powershell> dotnet

Microsoft .NET Core Shared Framework Host

  Version  : 1.0.1
  Build    : cee57bf6c981237d80aa1631cfe83cb9ba329f12
```

So I thought this may have been my issue but it actually was not and once I worked out my real issue, this version worked fine.

comments.author: andschwa
comments.body:
I'd be surprised if Start-PSBootstrap installed 1.0.1, as it uses the [obtain script](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/b5f4e595cd0f7d5e6212b842173b2f5552b9e7fd/build.psm1#L712) tied to their 1.0.0 branch, and specifically installs the latest from their [rel-1.0.1](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/b5f4e595cd0f7d5e6212b842173b2f5552b9e7fd/build.psm1#L655) channel.

This could only happen if they're hosting bad versions in their feed, and if that's the case, we should alert them.

It's great to know that 1.0.1 works now, we had quite a few problems with it previously.

Also, for what it's worth, the obtain scripts still provide me and the CI ([AppVeyor](https://ci.appveyor.com/project/PowerShell/powershell/build/6.0.0-alpha.8-4793#L25) and [Travis](https://travis-ci.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/jobs/47865523#L358)) systems with 1.0.0-preview3-003223.

comments.author: mwrock
comments.body: Ok. I'll double check my environment. I was working from a clean 2016 tp5 vm, but it wouldn't be the first time I inadvertently installed something via some other installer.

comments.author: andschwa
comments.body: You're not the only one to have seen it happen, but I'm utterly confused how.

comments.author: mwrock
comments.body:
Looks like what advertises itself as 1.0.0 preview 3 is in fact 1.0.1.

```
C:\dev\powershell [submodule +3 ~0 -0 !]> iwr https://dotnetcli.blob.core.windows.net/dotnet/Sdk/1.0.0-preview3-003223/dotnet-dev-win-x64.1.0.0-preview3-003223.zip -OutFile dotnet-dev-win-x64.1.0.0-preview3-003223.zip
C:\dev\powershell [submodule +3 ~0 -0 !]> Expand-Archive -Path .\dotnet-dev-win-x64.1.0.0-preview3-003223.zip
C:\dev\powershell [submodule +4 ~0 -0 !]> Get-ItemProperty -Path .\dotnet-dev-win-x64.1.0.0-preview3-003223\dotnet.exe | fl


    Directory: C:\dev\powershell\dotnet-dev-win-x64.1.0.0-preview3-003223

Length         : 127488
CreationTime   : 8/15/2016 10:03:59 PM

                 review3-003223\dotnet.exe

                 OriginalFilename: dotnet
                 FileVersion:      1,0,004500,00,1.0.1,
                 cee57bf6c981237d80aa1631cfe83cb9ba329f12 built by:
                 DOTNET-CLI-W002, UTC: 6/16/2016 3:10:50 AM
                 FileDescription:  dotnet
                 Product:          Microsoft® .NET Core Framework
                 ProductVersion:   1.0.1,
                 cee57bf6c981237d80aa1631cfe83cb9ba329f12 built by:

C:\dev\powershell [submodule +4 ~0 -0 !]> .\dotnet-dev-win-x64.1.0.0-preview3-003223\dotnet.exe

Microsoft .NET Core Shared Framework Host

  Version  : 1.0.1
  Build    : cee57bf6c981237d80aa1631cfe83cb9ba329f12

Usage: dotnet [common-options] [[options] path-to-application]

```

comments.author: andschwa
comments.body: Hm. That _really_ seems like they're sending us the wrong bits! I'd file a bug but it's apparently not breaking anything. Confusing nonetheless though.

comments.author: mwrock
comments.body: Yeah. Seems appropriate to apply this and remove the 1.0.1 note so users with compile issues don't try to chase the version.

comments.author: andschwa
comments.body:
I think the 1.0.1 install is Windows specific. I'm getting:

``` sh
dotnet --version
1.0.0-preview3-003180
```

On Ubuntu 14.04.

comments.author: andschwa
comments.body:
Oh, actually, this is just confusing information from `dotnet`, watch:

``` powershell
~ |-/ Start-PSBootstrap
Installing Open PowerShell build dependencies
dotnet-install: Downloading https://dotnetcli.blob.core.windows.net/dotnet/Sdk/1.0.0-preview3-003223/dotnet-dev-win-x64.
1.0.0-preview3-003223.zip
dotnet-install: Extracting zip from https://dotnetcli.blob.core.windows.net/dotnet/Sdk/1.0.0-preview3-003223/dotnet-dev-
win-x64.1.0.0-preview3-003223.zip
dotnet-install: Adding to current process PATH: "C:\Users\andschwa\AppData\Local\Microsoft\dotnet\". Note: This change w
ill not be visible if PowerShell was run as a child process.
dotnet-install: Installation finished
WARNING:
Skipping installation of chocolatey, cause both cmake and Win 10 SDK are present.
Cmake is already installed. Skipping installation.
Windows 10 SDK present. Skipping installation.

~ |-/ dotnet --info
.NET Command Line Tools (1.0.0-preview3-003223)

Product Information:
 Version:            1.0.0-preview3-003223
 Commit SHA-1 hash:  9d3b727392

Runtime Environment:
 OS Name:     Windows
 OS Version:  10.0.14393
 OS Platform: Windows
 RID:         win10-x64

~ |-/ dotnet --version
1.0.0-preview3-003223

~ |-/ dotnet

Microsoft .NET Core Shared Framework Host

  Version  : 1.0.1
  Build    : cee57bf6c981237d80aa1631cfe83cb9ba329f12

Usage: dotnet [common-options] [[options] path-to-application]

Common Options:
  --help                           Display .NET Core Shared Framework Host help.
  --version                        Display .NET Core Shared Framework Host version.

Options:
  --fx-version <version>           Version of the installed Shared Framework to use to run the application.
  --additionalprobingpath <path>   Path containing probing policy and assemblies to probe for.

Path to Application:
  The path to a .NET Core managed application, dll or exe file to execute.

If you are debugging the Shared Framework Host, set 'COREHOST_TRACE' to '1' in your environment.

To get started on developing applications for .NET Core, install .NET SDK from:
  http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=798306&clcid=0x409
```

I think they're trying to state that the `dotnet` _executable_ component (the shared host) is at version 1.0.1; but the _tools_ are still 1.0.0.

That said, I don't think they're even providing the 1.0.1 `dotnet` tools any more.

comments.author: mwrock
comments.body:
oh weird. yeah I see the same on ubuntu 1.0.0 with `--version` and 1.0.1 spit out from a parameterless call to the cli. What you say makes sense.

Wouldn't want to make this stuff too easy :)

comments.author: TravisEz13
comments.body: Please resolve all merge conflicts.  For more information see [GitHowTo - 30. Resolving Conflicts](http://githowto.com/resolving_conflicts)

comments.author: mwrock
comments.body: sure @TravisEz13. I am closing here and recreated in #2030 since I had to whack my original forked repo.

title: Remove misleading note about dotnet 1.0.1
